{{NCAATeamSeason |Mode=Basketball |Year=1986-87 |Prev year=1985-86 |Next year=1987-88 |Team=Syracuse Orangemen |Image= |Conference=Big East Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Big East |CoachRank= |APRank= |Record=31-7 <ref name=SUathletics>{{cite web |url= http://suathletics.com/Sports/basketball/mbasket/2006/mbbstats8687.asp|title= SU Athletics - 1986-87 Final (31-7, 12-4)|accessdate=2008-07-08 |work= |publisher= [[Syracuse University]]|date= }}</ref> |ConfRecord=12-4 |HeadCoach=[[Jim Boeheim]] |AsstCoach1=[[Bernie Fine]] |AsstCoach2= |AsstCoach3= |StadiumArena=[[Carrier Dome]] |Champion= |BowlTourney= |BowlTourneyResult= }} The '''1986-1987 Syracuse Orangemen basketball team''' represented [[Syracuse University]] in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] men's [[college basketball|competition]] in the 1986â87 season. The Head coach was [[Jim Boeheim]], serving for his 11th year.<ref name=SUathJB>{{cite web |url=http://suathletics.com/Pdfs/basketball/mbasket/2006/4/17/JByearbyyear.pdf|title= Jim Boeheim Year by Year|accessdate=2008-07-08|publisher=Syracuse University}}</ref> The team played home games at the [[Carrier Dome]] in [[Syracuse, New York]]. The team finished with a 31-7 (12-4) record while making it to the Championship game of the [[1987 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA tournament]].
The team was led by junior [[Rony Seikaly]] and sophomore [[Sherman Douglas]]. Seniors Greg Monroe and [[Howard Triche]], and freshman [[Derrick Coleman]] also played key roles.
==Season recap==
After the graduation of [[Rafael Addison]] and [[Wendell Alexis]] and the early departure of [[Pearl Washington]], expectations for the season were low.<ref name=OrangeHoops/>
But behind the surprising Sherman Douglas and Derrick Coleman, and despite an early injury to Rony Seikaly, Syracuse won its first 15 games en route to winning the Big East regular season title.<ref name=nytimesgoodstart>{{cite news |url= http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE4DD1131F93BA25752C0A961948260 |title=COLLEGE BASKETBALL '87: SYRACUSE; New Talent Bolsters 15-0 Syracuse |accessdate=2008-07-08 |work= |publisher= [[New York Times]]|date=1987-01-18 | first=William C. | last=Rhoden}}</ref> The season included thrilling victories over [[St. Johns Red Storm|St. Johns]] (64-63)<ref name=stjohns>{{cite news |url= http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE4D8133FF936A15752C0A961948260 |title= COLLEGE BASKETBALL; SYRACUSE HOLDS OFF ST. JOHN'S |accessdate=2008-07-08 |work= |publisher= [[New York Times]]|date=1987-01-25 }}</ref> and [[Seton Hall Pirates|Seton Hall]] (84-80).<ref name=setonhall>{{cite news |url= http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE2DA1038F937A35751C0A961948260 |title=SYRACUSE SURVIVES DOGGED SETON HALL |accessdate=2008-07-08 |work= |publisher= [[New York Times]]|date=1987-02-04 | first=William C. | last=Rhoden}}</ref>
Syracuse would defeat [[Villanova Wildcats|Villanova]] and [[Pittsburgh Panthers|Pittsburgh]] to advance to the Big East Championship game before falling to [[Georgetown Hoyas|Georgetown]], 69-59.<ref name=bigeastchampionshipgameloss>{{cite news |url= http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE2D6123EF93AA35750C0A961948260 |title= Williams Connects As Georgetown Wins Big East |accessdate=2008-07-08 |work= |publisher= [[New York Times]]|date=1987-03-09 | first=William C. | last=Rhoden}}</ref>
==NCAA tournament==
After finishing the regular season at 28-6, the Orangemen earned a 2 seed in the East region of the NCAA Tournament.<ref name=SHRP>{{cite web |url=http://www.shrpsports.com/collbask/1987.htm|title=1987 NCAA Basketball Tournament bracket|accessdate=2008-07-08|publisher=Shrp Sports}}</ref>
Syracuse played its first two tournament games at home in the Carrier Dome. The Orangemen defeated 15 seed [[Georgia Southern Eagles|Georgia Southern]] 79-73 and 10 seed [[Western Kentucky Hilltoppers|Western Kentucky]] 104-86 to advance to the Sweet 16.
After winning its first two tournament games at the Carrier Dome, the Orangemen moved on to the Sweet 16 held at [[Meadowlands Sports Complex|The Meadowlands]] in [[East Rutherford, New Jersey|East Rutherford]], [[New Jersey]].<ref name=SHRP/> The Orangemen defeated 6 seed [[Florida Gators|Florida]] 87-81.<ref name=SUathletics/>
Syracuse faced 1 seed [[North Carolina Tar Heels|North Carolina]] in the regional finals. The Orangemen had to fight off the Tar Heels down the stretch as they fought to overcome a 15 point Syracuse lead.<ref name=NYTheels>{{cite web|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE7DE153BF931A15750C0A961948260&scp=15&sq=1987%20basketball%20national%20championship&st=cse|title=COLLEGE BASKETBALL: EAST REGIONAL SYRACUSE, PROVIDENCE GAIN FINAL 4; TAR HEELS HURT BY REBOUNDING|accessdate=2008-07-08|author=Malcom Moran|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=22 March 1987}}</ref> However, Syracuse was able to hold off the Tar Heels, winning 79-75 to advance to the Final Four.<ref name=SUathletics/>
In the semi-final game, the Orangemen defeated fellow Big East team and 6 seed [[Providence Friars|Providence]] 77-63<ref name=SUathletics/>. The Orangemen had an easy time with the Friars, out rebounding them 53-35 with Coleman, Douglas, and Triche each having at least 10 rebounds.<ref name=OrangeHoops>{{cite web |url=http://www.orangehoops.org/1986-1987.htm|title=Syracuse Basketball 1986-1987|accessdate=2008-07-08|publisher=RLYoung|year=2006}}</ref> The Orangemen held the Friars to 36.4% shooting leading Coach Boeheim to credit the team's defense for the win.<ref name=NYTfriars>{{cite web|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DEED91638F93AA15750C0A961948260&scp=4&sq=1987%20basketball%20national%20championship&st=cse|title=COLLEGE BASKETBALL: SYRACUSE AND INDIANA REACH FINAL; ORANGEMEN COOL FRIAR'S SHOOTING |accessdate=2008-07-08|author=Roy S. Johnson|publisher=New York Times|date=29 March 1987}}</ref> The Orangemen also held Providence's leading scorer and future Florida Gators head coach [[Billy Donovan]] to 8 points, 18 under his season average.<ref name=NYTfriars/>
In the championship game at the [[Louisiana Superdome|Superdome]] in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], the Orangemen matched up against the [[Indiana Hoosiers]] coached by [[Bobby Knight]].<ref name=SUathletics/><ref name=OrangeHoops/> The game was a back and forth battle down until the final whistle. The Orangemen had a one point lead with 28 seconds left in the second half when Coleman missed the front end of a one and one. Indiana grabbed the rebound and tournament [[NCAA Basketball Tournament Most Outstanding Player|MOP]] [[Keith Smart]] made a [[jump shot (basketball)|jumper]] from the corner with just seconds left on the clock to give the Hoosiers a one point lead and the National Championship.<ref name=NYTfinal>{{cite web|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DEEDD103CF932A05750C0A961948260&sec=&spon=&&scp=4&sq=1987%20basketball%20national%20championship%20indiana&st=cse|title=PLAYERS; KNIGHT'S METHODS WIN ONCE MORE|author=Malcom Moran|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2008-07-08|date=31 March 1987}}</ref>
==Key contributors==
*Sherman Douglas (17.3 pts, 7.6 asts) *Rony Seikaly (15.1 pts, 8.2 rebs) *Greg Monroe (12.9 pts, 4.1 asts) *Derrick Coleman (11.9 pts, 8.8 rebs) *Howard Triche (11.8 pts, 4.8 rebs) *Steve Thompson (5.1 pts, 1.8 rebs)
==NCAA Tournament school records==
The team's 104 point outburst against Western Kentucky in the second round is tied for the most points in a tournament game.<ref name=SUncaa/>
Rony Seikaly's 138 points is a school record and was tied with Indiana's [[Steve Alford]] for most in that year's tournament.<ref name=SUncaa>{{cite web|url=http://suathletics.com/Pdfs/basketball/mbasket/2006/4/12/NCAARecords.pdf|title=SU NCAA Tournament Records|publisher=Syracuse University|accessdate=2008-07-08}}</ref> He also set records for [[field goal (basketball)|field goals]] and [[free throw]]s made with 53 and 51, respectively.<ref name=SUncaa/>
Derrick Coleman's 19 [[rebound (basketball)|rebounds]] against Indiana is a school record that still stands as of 2008. He also set tournament records for rebounds and blocked shots with 73 and 16, respectively.<ref name=SUncaa/>
Sherman Douglas set a record for assists with 49.<ref name=SUncaa/>
